facts.text: This is a Criminal Appeal No. 5 of 1970 by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 22, 1966 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 836 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal 5 of 1970 Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 22, 19166 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 836 of 1964.

facts.text: Five appellants challenged their conviction under sections 148 and 325/149 IPC and sentence of rigorous imprisonment for two years on each count with additional fine of Rs. 200/- each and in default six months RI, upheld by Punjab and Haryana High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave, five appellants have challenged their companyviction under ss. 148 and 325/149, P.C. and sentence of rigorous imprisonment for two Years on each companynt with additional fine of Rs. 200/- each under ss. 325/149, I.P.C. and in default of payment of fine further rigorous imprisonment for six months, up- held by a learned Single Judge of the Punjab and Haryana High Court on appeal from the judgment and order of the Sessions Judge, Ferozepur.

facts.text: Originally, 13 persons including the five appellants were tried by the Sessions Judge, Ferozepur under ss. 148, 307/149 and 364 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Originally, 13 persons including the five appellants were tried by the Sessions Judge, Ferozepur under ss. 148, 307/149 and 364, I.P.C.

facts.text: On August 11, 1963, between 7 and 8 a.m., Dharamvir PW9 started from village Ramsara for his land in Azamgarh area driving a bullock cart with wife Nathi PW5, brother's wife Ankori PW6, small girl Guddi, and Chandu; brother Jaidev PW4 walking behind.

anchor.surface_text: According to the broad features of the prosecution story, on August 11, 1963, Dharamvir P.W.9 started from his village Ramsara for his land in the area of Azamgarh some time between 7 and 8.00 a.m. He was driving a bullock cart and with him were his wife Nathi, P.W.5, his brothers wife Ankori, P.W.6, and a small girl Guddi as also one Chandu, in the said cart. Walking behind the cart was his brother Jaidev, P.W.4.

facts.text: After covering about 1.5 miles from Ramsara near Ranbir appellant's land, three jeeps overtook the cart: one in front obstructing, one by east side, one behind; all 13 accused emerged armed with weapons.

anchor.surface_text: When they had companyered a distance of about 1 1/2 miles from the village Ramsara and were near the land of Ranbir appellant three jeeps overtook their cart from behind. One jeep stood in front of the cart and obstructed its passage another jeep stood by the side of the cart towards the east and the third one was behind it. All the 13 accused persons armed with various weapons emerged from the three jeeps.

facts.text: Ranbir appellant carried a spiked dang known as sela, Laxmi appellant armed with kuthari, Hanuman with gun, remaining appellants with lathis.

anchor.surface_text: We are number companycerned with the other accused persons who are number before us. Ranbir appellant was stated to be carrying a spiked dang known as sela. Laxmi appellant was stated to be armed with a kuthari Hanuman appellant was armed with a gun and the remaining appellants with lathis.

facts.text: Accused pulled Dharamvir from cart and beat him with weapons; Jaidev intervened to save brother but beaten by Ranbir, Laxmi and another with weapons.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the accused persons pulled down Dharamvir from the cart. All of them started be labouring him with their respective weapons. Jaidev, brother of Dharamvir, intervened in order to save his brother, but he was also be laboured by Ranbir and Laxmi appellants along with another accused person, with their respective weapons.

facts.text: Shrimati Ankori (Jaidev's wife) and Shrimati Nathi (Dharamvir's wife) tried to protect husbands and were beaten by some accused.

anchor.surface_text: Shrimati Ankori, wife of Jaidev and Shrimati Nathi, wife, of Dharamvir, who tried to protect their respective husbands against further injuries, were also be laboured by some of the accused persons.

facts.text: Tota Ram PW7 and Hardwari PW8 of Ramsara village witnessed the occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: Tota Ram P.W.7 and Hardwari P.W.8 of Ramsara village also witnessed the occurrence.

facts.text: Accused lifted injured Dharamvir and Jaidev, put them in one jeep driven east; in Ranbir's field, Jaswant wrapped gunny bag on Dharamvir's knees, Laxmi placed 5 seer iron weight under knee, Ranbir and Sahi Ram struck hammer blows on knee.

anchor.surface_text: After causing injuries both to Dharamvir and Jaidev, the accused persons are stated to have lifted them both and put into one of the jeeps which was driven away towards the east. In the field of Ranbir, Jaswant appellant is stated to have wrapped a gunny bag round the knees, of Dharamvir and Laxmi appellant to have placed a five seer iron weight under the knee. Ranbir appellant and Sahi Ram accused are then stated to have struck hammer blows on Dharamvirs knee.

facts.text: Jaidev taken 20 karams away, given similar knee injuries by Ranbir, Jaswant, Laxmi and Sahi Ram.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, Jaidev was removed to a distance of about 20 karams from his brother Dharamvir and given similar injuries on his knee by Ranbir, Jaswant, Laxmi appellant and Sahi Ram accused.

facts.text: Injured put back in jeep to be cut into pieces and thrown in pucca canal ahead of Abohar towards Fazilka; jeeps driven towards Abohar.

anchor.surface_text: After causing them these injuries, Dharamvir and Jaidev Were again put in one jeep with the object of cutting them into pieces and throwing them in the pucca canal. The three jeeps are then stated to have been driven away towards Abohar.

facts.text: At katcha canal 11 miles from Abohar towards Ramsara, one jeep returned to Ramsara, two proceeded to Abohar.

anchor.surface_text: On the way when the jeeps reach a katcha canal at a distance of about 11 miles from Abobar towards Ramsara, one of the jeeps returned to Ramsara, whereas the remaining two jeeps went ahead towards Abohar.

facts.text: Near Abohar police station, injured raised alarm; accused dropped them roadside short distance from PS and drove back.

anchor.surface_text: When the jeeps companytaining Dharamvir and Jaidev reached near the, police station Abohar, the two injured person raised alarm. The occupants of the jeep thereupon dropped Dhiaramvir and Jaidev on the road side at a short distance from the police station and themselves drove back.

facts.text: ASI Bhagat Singh and policemen arrived; SI Bhagat Singh recorded Jaidev's statement sent to PS, FIR Exh. P.G./2 recorded.

anchor.surface_text: Within a few minutes, A.S.I., Bhagat Singh and some other police men arrived from the police station. S.I., Bhagat Singh, recorded Jaidevs statement which was sent to the police station and on the basis of that statement F.I.R. Exh. P.G./2 was recorded.

facts.text: Jaidev and Dharamvir taken to Civil Hospital Abohar, then compounder gave first aid to four injured (including Ankori, Nathi, Guddi), taken to Fazilka Hospital; Dharamvir advised removal to Ferozepur Civil Hospital.

anchor.surface_text: Jaidev and Dharamvir were removed to the civil hospital, Abohar. A short while thereafter, Smt. Ankori and Smt. Nathi along with Guddi also reached the Civil Hospital, Abohar. The doctor in charge was, however, number available but the companypounder gave first aid to the four injured persons, Who were then taken to Fazilka Hospital where Dr. Parkash Kaur of the Civil Hospital advised Dharamvirs immediate removal to the Civil Hospital, Ferozepur.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted Moman giving benefit of doubt due to non-inclusion in FIR, lack of support by witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge on appraisal of the evidence led-in the case and after examining all the relevant circumstances numbericed the number-inclusion of the name of Moman accused in the F.I.R. and companycluded that it was- doubtful if Jaidev had merely forgotten to mention his name at that stage because, Tota Ram P.W.7 had also number supported the prosecution version with respect to Momans participation,  ii  Hardwari Lal P.W.8, Smt. Nathi P.W. 5 and Smt. Ankori P.W.6 had also failed to identify Moman as one of the culprits, and Jaidev P.W.4 and Dharamvir, P.W.9 had also number ascribed any particular injury to this accused.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted remaining 12 accused.

anchor.surface_text: Moman was accordingly given benefit of doubt and acquitted of all the charges. The remaining 12 accused persons were, however, held guilty of the offences charged and companyvicted as already numbericed.

facts.text: High Court upheld conviction of five appellants (Ranbir, Hanuman, Jaswant, Laxmi, Hari Ram) as eye-witness testimony consistent for them; acquitted other accused giving benefit of doubt due to identification issues and enmity.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge then went into the evidence and came to the companyclusion that the testimony of the eye witness was companysistent With regard to the participation of Ranbir, Hanuman, Jaswant and Laxmi appellants in the occurrence in question and excepting Hardwari P.W. 8, all the eye witnesses had deposed to the participation of Hari Ram appellant as well. ... Accepting the substratum of the prosecution case, the learned Single Judge after scrutiny of the testimony of the eye witnesses gave benefit ,of doubt to the other appellants before him except the five appellants Who have appealed to this Court.

facts.text: There was admitted enmity between the parties.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued in the High Court that the testimony of the eye witnesses was number worthy. of acceptance because of the admitted enmity between the parties and of the various discrepancies in their depositions.

facts.text: Supreme Court accepted evidence against five appellants as proving guilt beyond reasonable doubt, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the evidence believed by both the companyrts with respect to the five appellants before us is acceptable, and, if accepted, it certainly proves their guilt beyond reasonable doubt. ... The appeal must, therefore, fail and is dismissed.

facts.text: Tota Ram PW7 hid for four days out of fear and was examined by police after considerable delay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companynsel also faintly companytended that Tota Ram P.W.7 was examined by the police after companysiderable delay, the suggestion being that his evidence must be looked at with suspicion. ... Tota Ram, P.W.7 has stated that it was out of fear of the accused persons that he had hidden himself for four days.

facts.text: ASI Bhagat Singh attached to Abohar PS in Aug 1963, heard cries, rushed to spot, found injured; Parphul Singh Inspector took over investigation on August 12, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that Bhagat Singh, Assistant Sub- Inspector, C.I.D. Interrogation Centre, was attached to police station, Abohar in August, 1963 and it was he, who having heard cries like Mardiya Mardiya from outside the police station, had rushed to the spot and found Jaidev and Dharam Vir lying injured on the road. On August 12, 1963, Parphul Singh, Inspector, C.I.D. took over investigation from Bhagat Singh.

facts.text: Tracks of only one jeep were traceable though three jeeps used.

anchor.surface_text: A faint suggestion has also been made that although according to the prosecution version, there were three jeeps engaged in the companymission of the offence, tracks of only one jeep were traceable, with the result that the prosecution story as a whole must be companysidered to be untrustworthy.

issues.text: Whether there is any infirmity in the judgment of the High Court justifying interference under Article 136 of the Constitution?
Whether the evidence proves the guilt of the five appellants under Sections 148 and 325/149 IPC beyond reasonable doubt?

anchor.surface_text: their conviction under ss. 148 and 325/149, P.C. and sentence of rigorous imprisonment for two Years on each count with additional fine of Rs. 200/- each under ss. 325/149, I.P.C.

arguments.claim: Testimony of eye-witnesses not worthy of acceptance due to admitted enmity between parties and discrepancies in depositions, leading to danger of false implication; if court cannot separate truth from falsehood, all appellants entitled to benefit of doubt and acquittal

anchor.surface_text: It was argued in the High Court that the testimony of the eye witnesses was not worthy. of acceptance because of the admitted enmity between the parties and of the various discrepancies in their depositions. It was contended that in view of the highly strained relations between the parties there was a danger of false implication and if the Court could not separate truth from falsehood, all the appellants were entitled to the benefit of doubt and to be acquitted.

holdings.text: The evidence believed by both the courts with respect to the five appellants is acceptable and proves their guilt under ss. 148 and 325/149 IPC beyond reasonable doubt.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the evidence believed by both the courts with respect to the five appellants before us is acceptable, and, if accepted, it certainly proves their guilt beyond reasonable doubt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both lower courts found consistent eyewitness testimony identifying participation of five appellants; substratum of prosecution case intact after sifting evidence.

holdings.text: There is no infirmity in the High Court judgment justifying interference under Article 136 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We are wholly unable to find any infirmity in its judgment which would justify interference under Article 136 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court conclusions on facts final absent serious defect in appraisal or failure of justice; arguments relate to mere re-appraisal of evidence.

holdings.text: The maxim falsus in uno falsus in omnibus is not a sound rule to apply in the conditions in this country.

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out in Deep Chand v. State of Haryana, the maxim falsus in uno falsus in omnibus is not a sound rule to apply in the conditions in this country

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Deep Chand precedent; court duty to scrutinize remaining evidence with care if substratum intact and trustworthy.

holdings.text: Delay in examining Tota Ram PW7 does not render his evidence unreliable.

anchor.surface_text: The fact of delayed examination of Tota Ram should, in our opinion, have been put to- the Investigating Officer so as to enable him to explain the undue delay, if any, in examining Tota Ram.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delay material only if put to IO and suggestive of unfair practice to introduce false witness; explained by witness fear; IOs not questioned.

holdings.text: In cases of party factions with enmity, prosecution witnesses tend to implicate innocents but unlikely to spare actual offenders if substratum reliable; court must sift evidence carefully.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, in cases of party factions, there is generally speaking, a tendency on the part of the prosecution witnesses to implicate some innocent persons also along with the guilty ones,

holdings.reasoning_summary: General substratum reliable; eyewitnesses consistent on five appellants despite enmity; benefit of doubt given to others on identification.

holdings.text: Tracing tracks of only one jeep despite three jeeps does not falsify the prosecution story.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel forgets that the three jeeps were not supposed to run side by side. If the jeeps were running one behind the other, practically one track of the jeep could be noticed,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jeeps likely one behind other producing single track; trial court explanation accepted; no discrepancy with eyewitnesses; not pressed in High Court.

holdings.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must, therefore, fail and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of above holdings upholding convictions and no ground for interference.

State of Haryana 1 , the maxim falsus in uno falsus in omnibus is number a sound rule to apply in the companyditions in this companyntry and therefore, it is the duty of the Court in cases where a witness has been found to have given unreliable evidence in regard to certain particulars, to scrutinise the rest of his evidence with care and caution. precedents.case_name: Deep Chand v State of Haryana
precedents.cited_proposition: The maxim falsus in uno falsus in omnibus is not a sound rule to apply in the conditions in this country; it is the duty of the court to scrutinise the rest of the evidence with care and caution if a witness has given unreliable evidence in regard to certain particulars, and uphold the prosecution case to the extent it is trustworthy if the substratum remains intact

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court judgment upheld, sustaining convictions under ss. 148 and 325/149 IPC and sentences of rigorous imprisonment for two years and fine.
